summary: An FBI communication from Baltimore to Miami forwarding a criminal referral from U.S. District Judge Joseph J. Farnan Jr. regarding an attempted $15 million bridge loan fraud involving Wintel Telecom Holdings Inc. and Jeffrey Epstein. The referral details Epstein's discovery of forged collateral documents purporting to secure the loan with U.S. Treasury Bonds, linking the fraud to subject John Raymond Macari. This document is a collection of faxes and financial records from December 2001 concerning a proposed $15 million bridge loan from Jeffrey Epstein to WinTel Telecom Holdings, Inc. for the acquisition of Winstar Communications, Inc. out of bankruptcy. The documents show the loan was to be secured by $130 million in U.S. Treasuries held by Century Capital, S.A., but the deal collapses when the fiduciary, Williams Management & Capital Group, Ltd., withdraws citing issues with verification and a fraudulent bank officer.

events.title: Attempted Winstar Bridge Loan Fraud
events.description: Laurence Zimmerman of Wintel Telecom Holdings Inc. attempted to obtain a $15 million bridge loan from Jeffrey Epstein to finance Wintel's acquisition of Winstar Communications Inc., offering forged collateral documents purporting to be U.S. Treasury Bonds.

events.title: Epstein Discovers Forgery
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein contacted Wells Fargo Bank and discovered the signature of bank officer 'Kevin Keon' on the collateral instruments was a forgery, and the bank had no knowledge of the documents.

events.title: Judge Farnan's Criminal Referral
events.description: U.S. District Judge Joseph J. Farnan Jr. referred the matter to U.S. Attorney Colm F. Connolly for investigation, enclosing Epstein's letter and related documents.

events.title: FBI Baltimore Forwards Referral to Miami
events.description: The FBI's Baltimore Division forwarded Judge Farnan's criminal referral to the Miami Division for investigative action, linking the fraud to the existing case against John Raymond Macari.

events.title: Issuance of Custodial Receipt for $20M Treasuries
events.description: Williams Management & Capital Group, Ltd. issues a receipt acknowledging receipt of $20 million in U.S. Treasury Bonds for the benefit of Century Capital, S.A., and WinTel.

events.title: Bridge Financing Proposal and Commitment Letter
events.description: Jay Phillip Parker requests Jeffrey Epstein confirm funding ability. A commitment letter is drafted to Judge Faman confirming $15M is available to fund WinTel's purchase of Winstar.

events.title: Collapse of Bridge Loan Transaction
events.description: Laurence Zimmerman writes to Jeffrey Epstein explaining the deal is off because the $130 million in U.S. Treasuries offered as primary collateral appear to be fictitious or unverifiable.

events.title: Williams Management Withdraws from Transaction
events.description: S. Williams sends a letter to Zimmerman and Whittier declaring all prior documentation null and void, citing inability to verify security details and fraud by an individual posing as a Wells Fargo officer.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was targeted in an attempted $15 million bridge loan fraud involving forged U.S. Treasury Bond documents.
The fraud was linked to John Raymond Macari, a subject of an existing FBI money laundering investigation, who falsely claimed ownership of the bond CUSIP numbers.
Epstein personally investigated and uncovered the forgery by contacting Wells Fargo Bank, preventing any financial loss.
U.S. District Judge Joseph J. Farnan Jr. formally referred the case to the U.S. Attorney as a potential criminal matter.
The FBI communication shows early (2002) federal law enforcement awareness of Epstein in the context of a financial fraud scheme, not related to sexual abuse.
Jeffrey Epstein was positioned to provide a $15 million bridge loan to WinTel Telecom Holdings, Inc. for acquiring Winstar Communications out of bankruptcy in December 2001.
The primary collateral for the loan was $130 million in U.S. Treasury Bonds supposedly held by Century Capital, S.A. and custodied with Williams Management & Capital Group, Ltd.
The deal fell apart when the Treasury securities could not be verified and were suspected to be 'clearly fictitious,' according to WinTel principal Laurence Zimmerman.
Williams Management & Capital Group withdrew entirely, citing verification problems and fraud involving an individual falsely representing themselves as a Wells Fargo Bank officer.
Laurence Zimmerman had offered a personal guarantee secured by high-value New York and Aspen real estate as secondary collateral, contingent on the Treasuries being valid.
